titleStmt.title: Tamiḻneṟi Viḷakkam 15.
Experimenting with formatting for the final edition.

witness.expan: A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [ante correctionem]
A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [post correctionem]
Kuṟuntokai 88. Maturaik Katakkaṇṇaṉ: the confidante / SHE
Kuṟuntokai 130. Veḷḷi Vīti(yār): the confidante / SHE

lg.l: [The hero's] desire becoming clear, [the hero's] fear of separation,
[the hero's] sweet-natured comfort, [the hero's] difficulty obtaining [her],
[the hero] saying "[she is like my] life", [the hero feeling] comforted and then departing
― [these are] the divine union of faultless love.

div.p: e-tu. collap paṭṭa pākiṉ uṭ ṭeyvap puṇarcci yām āṟuṇarttutaṉutaliṟṟu.
The quoted [cūttiram] intends to make known the way in which the divine union occurs amongst the aformentioned division.

muṟ cey viṉai kāraṇam ākak kaṇṇuṟṟup puṇarnta piṉpu talaimakaṉayappuṇarttalun teruṭṭalum pirivaccamum vaṉpoṟaiyum eytutal arumaiyum uyir eṉṟalum āṟṟip peyartalum eṉap paṭṭaṉa teyvap puṇarcci yām eṉṟa vāṟu.

After meeting and uniting on account of previous actionThis most likely refers to actions in their past lives, in which case this an allusion to that fact their relationship is divinely ordained. Or, it might be an elliptical reference to the 'prologue' mentioned in the apparatus notes., [the hero] expressing desire, [the heroine's state] becoming clear [to the hero], [the hero's] fear of separation, [the hero] comfort[ing her], [the hero's] difficulty obtaining [her], [the hero] saying, "[she is like my] life", and [the hero feeling] comforted and departing - these things are [how] divine union occurs.
[The heroine's] state becomes clear [to the hero].

lg.l: yamaiyē ṉiṉṉaiyā ṉakaṉṟa nāṉṟēThe Tamil Lexicon cites the Tivviya Pirapantam for this seemingly alternate spelling of the more well attested ñāṉṟu. Since this is the reading of UVSL950 and it is attested elsewhere, I have chosen to take it. I consider it a valid alternate spelling. I believe the other readings are corrections (in the case of UVSL48032, an incorrect attempted correction) or standardisations.
kaṇṇeṉa malarnta kāmar cuṉaimalarWere it not for the correction, this cīr would not be metrical.

div.p: [The hero] saying, "[She is like my] life."
eṉpatu teyvan tuṇai yākak koṇṭāṟṟip peyarntatu.
[The hero] thinks of his friend, feels comforted and leaves.

standOff.note: Cf. TP221i: pirital accam
Cf. IAC2, p.37: iṉit, teyvap puṇarcci eṉavum paṭum; iruvarum teyvattaṉmaiyāṟ puṇarntārākaliṉ eṉpatu.
Cf. TP487i.1: kāmap puṇarcciyum
Cf. IA2.2: kāmap puṇarcci
Cf. IAC2, p.37: iyaṟkaip punṇarcci eṉappaṭum; pulavarāṟ kūṟappaṭṭa iyalpiṉāṟ puṇarntārākalāṉum, kantaruva vaḻakkattoṭu otta iyalpiṉar puṇarntārākalāṉum eṉpatu.
Cf. IAC2, p.37: muṉṉuṟu puṇarcci eṉappaṭum; ivaḷnalam ivaṉāṉē muṉṟuṟa eytappaṭṭamaiyāṉum, ivaṉalam ivaḷāṉē muṉṉuṟa eytappaṭṭamaiyāṉum eṉpaṭu.
Cf. AV27.1: iyaṟkaip puṇarcci
Cf. AV32: teyvan taṉiṉe ytavuṅ kiḻattiyi | ṉeytavum paṭūu miyaṟkaip puṇarcci ||
Cf. AV33: iyaṟkaip puṇarcci teyvatti ṉeytuḻi | muyaṟciyiṉṟi muṭiva tākum ||
Cf. AV125: kalantuḻi makiḻtalum nalampā rāṭṭalu | mēṟpuṟa vaṇitalum eṉṉumim mūṉṟum | pēṟṟiya teyvap puṇarcciyiṉ viriyē ||

This cūttiram follows the same sequence as the IAC, but the corresponding passages are included as sources for the commentary. This is because the wording was more similar in teh commentary, and in previous cases, the commentary has very clearly been closely based on the IAC, where the cūṭtiram has not been. This is to say that one should probably also consider this enumeration to follow in the footsteps of Nakkīraṉār. It is only for practical considerations namely that it would be a waste of space to report the same sources/parallels twice - that they only appear there.

A note on the terminology for this union. The later teyvap puṇarcci, found in this text, suggests a more moralistic karmic initial meeting - the union in this life has been fated due to two lovers' relationship in their past lives. As for kāmap puṇarcci, the term found in the oldest grammars, the precise connotation is not clear. Nakkīraṉār understands it as a union borne out of their increased desire when they meet alone (IAC2), in which case kāma carries a clear sexual undertone. Takanobu however argues convincingly that in the earliest strata of Tamil literature, kāma was a broader term that should be better translated as 'love' (Takanobu 1995: 66-7). The two other terms used for this meeting, at least according to Nakkīraṉār (IAC2), are also quite ambiguous. muṉṉuṟu puṇarcci refers to some previous union and is understood to refer ellipticaly this initial union and the most common term for this - iyaṟkaip puṇarcci - could also mean a number of things. The union maybe 'natural' as they chance upon each other, whereas their other meetings need to be organised through intermediaries, or because it has been divinely ordained. According Nakkīraṉār whom later scholars largely follow on this point, these four terms all refer to the exact same thing (IAC2 p.47).
vāṭkkai is noted as a western dialect variant by the Tamil Lexicon. No citations are provided. Thus, due to the lack of textual evidence and for ease of comprehension, I choose the standard spelling.

I find the spelling of jañciṟait quite curious. I am unaware or any dialect or orthographic norm that would represent ya as ja . Is this simply a mistake? This is also the only grantha character in the two TNV manuscripts.

Cf. PK5 (IAC2, p.42): tūvaṇtai vaṇṭiṉaṅ kāḷvammiṉ collumiṉ tuṉṉinillāk | kōvuṇṭai kōṭṭāṟ ṟaḻivitta kōṉkoṅka nāṭṭaceṅkēḻ | māvuṇṭai vāṭṭiya nōkkiṉ vārkuḻal pōṟkamaḻum | pūvaṇṭai tāmuḷa vōnukaḷ kāṉṟa poḻiliṭattē ||
Cf. PK6.3-4 (IAC2, p.42): marṅkuḻa luṅkaḷi vaṇṭiṉaṅ kāḷurai yīrmaṭantai | karuṅkuḻal nāṟumeṉ pōtuṭait tōnuṅ kaṭipoḻilē ||
Cf. PK7.2-4 (IAC2, p.43):...oḷimalarttā | tuṇṭē yuḻalvā maṟitiyaṉ ṟēyuḷa vēluraiyāy | vaṇṭē maṭantai kuḻalpōṟ kamaḻu matumalarē ||
Cf. PK8.2-4 (IAC2, p.43):...oṇ pōtukaṭam | maruṅkuḻal vāynī yaṟitivaṇ ṭēcol leṉakkumaṅkai | karuṅkuḻal pōluḷa vōvirai nāṟuṅ kaḷimalarē ||
Cf. PK9.2-4 (IAC2, p.43):...koṅ kuṇṭuḻalvāy | māṟṟa murainī yeṉakkuvaṇ ṭēmaṅkai vārkuḻalpōl | nāṟṟa muṭaiya uḷavō aṟiyu naṟumalarē ||
KT2 is also quoted in the commentary to IA2 (p.43) and is the earliest known occurence of this poetic topos.

IAC2, p.43: niṉaintu, aṟintēṉ eṉṉatu kātalmikaviṉāṟ pārāṭṭap pōlum eṉa uṇarntāṉ. uṇarntu, yāṉ taṉmuṉṉiṉṟu taṉṉaip pārāṭṭavum ivvakai melivu ceṉṟa perunāṇuṭaiyāḷ, puṟattu yārāṉum oruvar ivvoḻukkattai uṇarvārkollō eṉṟu uṭkoṇṭa ñāṉṟu ivaḷ iṟantupaṭumpōlum eṉap peryatōr āṟṟāt taṉmaiyaṉ āyiṉāṉ.
Cf. PK10.3-4 (IAC2, p.44): niṉṉiṟ piriyēṉ piriyiṉum āṟṟē ṉeṭumpaṇaittōṭ | poṉṉiṟ pacuntoḷi vāṭṭi eṉṉai pulampuvatē ||
Cf. PK11.3-4 (IAC2, p.44):... peyvaḷait tōḷiniṉ ṉiṟpiriyēṉ | maṇiniṟam poṉṉiṟa māyiṭa eṉṉai varuntvatē ||
Cf. PK12.3-4 (IAC2, p.44):...muciri | yaṉṉāy piriyēṉ piriryiṉum āṟṟē ṉaḻuṅkaṟkavē ||
Cf. IAC2, p.44: aṅṅaṉam āṟṟiṉāḷatu nīrmaiyaik kaṇṭu, 'ivaḷ evviṭattum taṉ taṉmaieṉpatu oṉṟu ivaḷ, eṉ taṉmaiyaḷē pōlum' eṉap peritōr kaḻiyuvakai mītūr niṉṟu, vaṉpuṟai eṉpatōr coṟcollum.

This is as much as anything a summation of the situation expressed in the TNVC poem. It is difficult to conclusively say this was the source of the quoted poem, however since the TNV commentator clearly follows the IAC in general, it is fair to assume this prose passage was the inspiration for this poem.
Cf. PK14.2-4 (IAC2, p.45):...toṇṭi yaṉṉāy tuyaralemmūr | maṇiniṟa maṭattu maṭṭiya vāñcuṭar mālainummūr | aṇiniṟa māḷikai mēṟpakal pārit taṇavarumē ||
Cf. IAC2, p.45: 'emperumāṉ aṇittu em iṭam eṉkiṉṟāṉāl, aṇiyataṟku arumaiyillai eṉkiṉṟāṉām.'
Cf. AV129.4: itamaṇit teṉṟalum...

The IAC has been cited as it mirrors the basic syntax of the TNVC poem, and has the same basic idea - their towns are close together and so he will be able to visist her easily and regularly. This is expressed in the prose passage quoted, where she realises what he is saying and feels comforted.
The AV closely mirrors the language found in the IAC prose passage quoted.
Cf. PK17.3-4 (IAC2, p.46):...meṉ tōḷitaṉ ṉākam puṇarntatellām | kaṉavē naṉavāy vaṭiṉmey tātiṉik kaṇṇuṟavē ||
Cf. PK18.3-4 (IAC2, p.46):... peṇṇaṇaṅkiṉ | tirunalañ cērntatrl lāṅkaṉa vēyeṉṟu cintippaṉē ||
Cf. IAC2, p.46: kaṭṭiṉāḷaik kaṇṭu, 'ivaḷai yāṉ eytiṉeṉ eṉak karutiṉaṉ' eytiyatu uṇṭēl kaṉavēpōlum! naṉave yāyiṉum ivaḷ eṉakku eytutaṟku ariyaḷām'

Cf. PK20 (IAC2, p.47): tēyat tavaruyi raippula ṉaṉṟeṉpar cennilattaik | kāyak kaṉaṉṟetirn tārmaru mattuk kaṭuṅkaṇaikaḷ | pāyac cilaikoṭṭa pañcavaṉ vañcippaim pūmpoḻillāy | āyat tiṭaiyatu vōtiri kiṉṟateṉ āruyirē ||

Cf. PK21 (IAC2, p.47): iṉṉuyir kaṇṭaṟi vārillai yeṉpa rikalmalaintār | maṉṉuyir vāṉceṉ ṟaṭaiyak kaṭaiyaluḷ veṉṟuvaiyan | taṉṉuyir pōlniṉṟu tāṅkumeṅ kōṇkollit tāḻpoḻilvāy | eṉṉuyi rāyat tiṭaiyitu vōniṉ ṟiyaṇkuvatē
IAC2, p.47: āṟṟuvatu yātō eṉiṉ, tāṉ eyti āraṇaṅkākiya avvuruviṉai niṉaintu, tāṉ eytum upāyamāvatu taṉ kātaṟṟōḻaṉai itukoṇṭu muṭikkuṅ kollō eṉpatu.
Cf. IAC2, p. 39: nayappu eṉpatu talaimakaṉ vaṇṭiṟku uraippāṉāyt talaimakaḷ kēṭpat taṉ nayappuṇarttiyatu.
Cf. IAC2, p. 44: pirivaccam eṉpatu, tāṉ pirivu añciṟṟum pirivaccam; avaḷaip pirivu añcuvittatum pirivaccam; ātaliṉ pirivaccam eṉappaṭṭatu.
Cf. IAC2, p. 45: vaṉpuṟai eṉpatu vaṟpuṟuttuvatu.
Cf. IAC2, p. 46: kāṭṭiṉāḷaik kaṇṭu, 'ivaḷai yāṉ eytiṉēṉ eṉak karutiṉaṉ. eytiyatu uṇṭēl kaṉāvēpōlum! naṉavē āyiṉum ivaḷ eṉakku eytutaṟku ariyaḷām' eṉa āṟṟāṉāyiṉāṉ.
Cf. IAC2, p. 47: atu paṟṟukkōṭāka āṟṟi nīṅkum eṉpatu.
Cf. AV128: aiyan tīrttal pirivuḻi vaṟuttaleṉ | ṟeytiya vaṉpuṟai yiruvakaittākum ||

There seems to be some confusion amongst scribes between the common vaṉpuṟai and vaṉpoṟai which we find in the TNV. Rajaretthinam records vaṉpoṟai as a variant for vaṉpuṟai in his edition of the AV. I am inclined to understand this as a simple orthographic variation, possibly a regional one, and so I have retained this uncommon form.

As the earliest known text which organises the speech situations (and the poems they describe) into a kōvai ('sequence'), and because of the clear similarities in phrasing, we should consider the IAC as a source for the TNV. The corresponding sections have been provided at some length, as they provide potentially valuable information not found in either the mūklam or the comparatively terse TNV commentary.

It is worth noting that the TNV begins its enumeration after what Takanobu has termed the 'prologue' (Takanobu 1995: 62) - four situations which precede their first union. The TP indrectly mentions them, the IA does not, the IAC mentions them explicitly, as does the AV. They are: kāṭci, aiyam, tuṇivu and kuṟippaṟital.
